data.text: Contents

1.1. This protocol has been developed to help with the management of physical and psychological distress in paediatric dressing changes and is to be used alongside the ‘top tips for managing distress in paediatric dressing changes'. It is aimed at those children who are finding dressing changes very distressing rather than as a routine protocol for all dressing changes. The dressing change tips handout is a useful guide for the management of all dressing changes whether or not distress is acutely visible.

1.2. The protocol has been developed with input from children and families themselves as well as a wide range of burns healthcare professionals including doctors, nurses, nursery nurses, physiotherapists, and play therapists.

1.3. It is not meant to be prescriptive but more to serve as a guideline to hopefully standardise the service's response to psychological distress during dressing changes. It has the ultimate aim of reducing the short and long term psychological and physical impact on our patients of distress during medical interventions.

Research has consistently found a link between psychological distress and reduced burn epithelisation. For example a recent study by Brown et al. (2019) found that child peak-procedural pain significantly accounted for 6% additional variance (alongside wound depth and size) in the time taken for re-epithelisation. Research demonstrating the link between procedural distress and short and long term psychological distress is vast. Distress during procedures can lead to continuing anxiety, separation anxiety, and problems with sleep, nightmares, irritability and aggressiveness long beyond the period of hospitalisation that can in turn impact on a child's cognitive, social and emotional development.

We are all aware that the level of psychological distress a child experiences in response to their burn injury and during medical procedures usually has no or very little correlation to the size or severity of their burn. Instead a number of factors are thought to influence the child's distress including parental distress, previous individual or familial trauma and pre-existing mental health or behavioural problems. It is important to remember this when completing medical procedures on seemingly small or nearly healed burns.

So how do we know when a child is distressed? Many of the children we support will have not yet developed the ability to verbalise their fears and worries about a procedure and when they are experiencing anxiety they are even less likely to be able to clearly tell us what is going on for them. This is why we will often see behavioural distress rather than emotional distress in the children we support. A child who is kicking, screaming, refusing to get undressed to be treated or examined, hitting and/or spitting is likely to be as scared (or perhaps even more so) as a child who is sitting still, crying and shaking.

This protocol is based on one very clear belief and that is that no school age child (any child aged 5 or over) should be being physically restrained in order for a dressing change to be completed. Restraint only further adds to a child's sense of loss of control and may make things worse in the short-term. In the long term restraint can have a long lasting impact on a child's emotional well-being.

Sedation is part of the protocol as a last resort when all other avenues have been explored; however it is important to note that sedation can and should be used in the case where it is psychological distress alone that is preventing completion of the dressing change. We understand that the decision to sedate a child is not one that can be taken lightly and also depends very much on the resources available at the time but we believe that in some cases it will be necessary for a child to be sedated in order for a necessary dressing change to be completed safely.

All staff within the children's burns care team are very skilled in managing distress during dressing changes, so this protocol has been developed to bring those skills together so that we can all continue to support our patients' physical and psychological healing post burn injury.
4.1.  The purpose of this document is to:
Reduce the short and long term psychological and physical impact on burns paediatric patients of distress during medical interventions.
Have a clear MDT agreed approach to managing distress during paediatric burns dressing changes.

data.text: 7.1. The environment
Try and prepare all equipment beforehand and keep it out of the child's sight as this can help reduce anticipatory anxiety.
Try and minimise the number of people in the room – ideally only one parent/carer and two or three healthcare professionals.
Consider the timing of removing the dressing - are doctors available if a review is needed?
7.2. The child
Try and establish some rapport with the child – ask them where they last went on holiday, what their favourite subject is at school, etc.
Assess the child/young person's developmental level – do they seem young or old for their age?

Ask about previous experience with similar procedures; Were these traumatic? Did they need to be sedated or physically restrained? What was done to reduce their distress and how successful was it? What do the parents and child/young person feel would help most?
Have they been given pain relief medication? Remember pain medication needs time to work; therefore you will need to wait for this to reach peak effect. See note below.
Check the child/young person's notes for information relating to previous procedural experiences and any recommendations.
Assess the child/young person's current level of distress in relation to this
procedure.
7.3. The parents

How did the parents find the last dressing change? What role did they take? Are they happy to take a similar role today or would they like support to do something different. How do the parents seem to be coping?

Evidence shows children do better with a parent/carer present but there are exceptions – e.g. when the parents show very high levels of distress or they themselves have severe procedural fears. ASK BEFORE! Parents/carers should not automatically be expected to be involved.

Do you need any additional help to support you in preparing the child/young person? If one is unavailable and you think you do need support can you ask another clinician? This is especially worth considering if a child is very frightened or has a history of difficult procedures.
7.5. Explanation

It can be helpful, especially if the child/young person has had the procedure before, to ask what they think is going to happen, check for misconceptions, and build your own explanation from that in a developmentally appropriate way.
Keep explanations short and developmentally appropriate.
Try and use honest but soft and least threatening words.

Explain what needs to be done, why it needs to be done, how it will feel (include description of any sensory experiences they can anticipate; e.g. what the procedure might feel like, any smells or sounds they might experience) and what the child/young person needs to do (e.g. sit very still, hold their arm still, or whatever is appropriate for the procedure).
Let them know how they might feel after the procedure.
Try not to give false reassurances – e.g. ‘this won't hurt'.
Give the child/young person and their family some idea of how long it will take e.g. ‘until we finish our song'; ‘five minutes'; ‘until the big hand gets to 10', etc. (but don't underestimate).

If the parent/carer is in the room involve them and encourage them to have an active role in supporting their child through positioning, holding and comforting them, as well as encouraging the use of appropriate coping strategies. Parents can also be very effective in using praise with their child/young person to reinforce co-operation and coping skills.
7.6. Communication
Continue to let the child know what's happening throughout the dressing change.

Give the child/young person appropriate control - They may be able to unwrap certain medical equipment, clean the area, or choose whether to sit up (on a chair or on a parent's lap) or lie down. They may also be able to give the signal when to start, or to indicate when they need a break in longer procedures.

Evidence suggests that giving children permission to make a noise can result in them experiencing less distress than if they are told not to cry and to be brave. Encourage them to cry or shout or roar like a lion. It can help if the parent and health care worker make the noise too.
Does the child want to look/not look? Use distraction and have one person take the lead on it.
Only one person should speak at a time during the procedure otherwise child can become confused or distracted from coping strategies.

Coping strategies – touch, music, singing, progressive muscle relaxation training, guided imagery, distraction, blowing away the pain (birthday cake - Blowing away the pain – have the child/young person imagine a birthday cake with candles. Suggest the child ‘blows out the discomfort/pain 'with a slow, steady breath), bubbles, relaxation – pretend to be a rag doll or a puppet whose strings have been cut.

Use positive directions wherever possible. The use of ‘don't' tends to convey a negative/punitive message instead tell them what they can do. Prepare them for success. ‘This is the time to hold still' is much more supportive than ‘don't move'.
Choose the best coping strategies for the child.
Minimise disturbances if possible.
Support parents with how they can position their child for the procedure.
If appropriate remind the child/young person that the pain will soon get better – but remain honest.

7.9. Flexibility - if problems arise…
7.10. After the Procedure

Praise the child/young person for what they have managed to do. Even if the procedure fails praise them for trying and reassure them that you will arrange for some help for them to assist them for next time.
Document what has been tried and what worked well.
Consider what support might be needed next time.
Do health professionals involved need support/debrief?
If the child is an outpatient request in the handover for follow-up call to parent/carers to be made the following day by ward staff if possible.
8.1. Pain medication is calculated based on a child's weight.
8.2. Remember there is an analgesia onset time and also duration of action which should be taken into account.
8.3. No oral ketamine or midazolam sedation to be used in children under 3 years of age.
8.4. Sedation requires an additional nurse to monitor obs. This nurse should not be directly involved in the dressing change.
8.5. Sedation requires the same starvation time as GA (6 hours without food, 1 hour without water).
